[[File:SWAT_team_prepared_%284132135578%29.jpg|thumb|right|[[SWAT]] team members, some armed with assault rifles, prepare for an exercise.]] [[File:LAPD Lakers Parade.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|right|A large group of [[Los Angeles Police Department]] (LAPD) SWAT officers in tactical gear at a [[Los Angeles Lakers|Lakers]] parade in 2009]] '''Militarization of police''' refers to the use of [[military equipment]] and [[Military tactics|tactics]] by [[law enforcement officer]]s. This includes the use of [[armored personnel carrier]]s, [[assault rifle]]s, [[submachine gun]]s, [[flashbang grenade]]s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eliteukforces.info/special-air-service/weapons/stun-grenade.php |title=SAS - Weapons - Flash Bang | Stun Grenade (The British Army's SAS developed flashbang grenades) |publisher=Eliteukforces.info |accessdate=May 29, 2013}}</ref><ref>The flash from a flashbang grenade detonation momentarily activates all [[photoreceptor cell]]s in the [[human eye|eye]], making vision impossible for approximately five seconds, until the eye restores itself to its normal, unstimulated state. The loud blast is meant to cause temporary loss of hearing, and also disturbs the [[Perilymph|fluid in the ear]], causing loss of balance. The concussive blast of the detonation can still injure, and the heat created can ignite flammable materials.</ref> [[grenade launcher]]s,<ref>Texas Rangers, Department of Public Safety, [http://www.txdps.state.tx.us/director_staff/public_information/branch_davidian/indexfirst.htm Branch Davidian Evidence], Investigative Report No. 1, September 1999; Investigative Report No. 2, January 2000 (PDFs available at Texas Rangers website). The Rangers found that the FBI used grenade launchers to fire two 40 mm M651 grenades. The Army considers the M651 a pyrotechnic device and that it is known to cause fires. The Army Tech Manual for the M651 warns that it can penetrate 3/4" plywood at 200 meters and "projectile may explode upon target impact." During inventory of the Waco evidence the Texas Rangers also found flashbang grenades.</ref> [[sniper rifle]]s, and [[Special Weapons and Tactics]] (SWAT) teams.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/militarization-of-police/| author=James Joyner| title=Militarization of Police| publisher=Outside the Beltway| date=June 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/ferguson-and-the-shocking-nature-of-us-police-militarization| author=Paul D. Shinkman| title=Ferguson and the Militarization of Police| publisher=U.S. News and World Report| date=August 14, 2014}}</ref> The [[militarization]] of law enforcement is also associated with [[intelligence agency]]-style information gathering aimed at the public and [[political activist]]s,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.defenseone.com/ideas/2014/12/why-police-spying-americans-everyones-problem/101598/| author= Michael German| title=Why Police Spying On Americans Is Everyone's Problem| publisher=Defense One| date=December 18, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/03/25/state-lawmakers-push-to-rein-in-police-spying/| author=Josh Peterson| title=State lawmakers push to rein in police spying| publisher=Fox News Channel| date=March 25, 2014}}</ref> and a more aggressive style of [[law enforcement]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/arizona/2014/06/24/aclu-reports-arizona-police-are-excessively-militarized/11288865/| author=Ryan Van Velzer| title=ACLU: Free military weapons making Arizona police more aggressive| work=The Arizona Republic| date=June 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.salon.com/2013/08/29/11_over_the_top_u_s_police_raids_that_victimized_innocents/| author=Jodie Gummow| title=11 over-the-top U.S. police raids that victimized innocents| work=Salon| date=August 29, 2013}}</ref> Criminal justice professor Peter Kraska has defined militarization of police as "the process whereby [[civilian]] police increasingly draw from, and pattern themselves around, the tenets of [[militarism]] and the military model."<ref>{{cite web| url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2014/08/14/militarization-u-s-police-dragged-light-horrors-ferguson/| author=GLENN GREENWALD| title=THE MILITARIZATION OF U.S. POLICE: FINALLY DRAGGED INTO THE LIGHT BY THE HORRORS OF FERGUSON| publisher=The Intercept|date=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
Observers have noted the militarizing of the policing of [[protest]]s.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/distributed/C/bo21636470.html|title=Crisis and Control|website=uchicago.edu}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/9/10/senate-police-militarization.html|title=Congress scrutinizes police militarization before planned Ferguson protest|website=aljazeera.com}}</ref> Since the 1970s, [[riot police]] have fired at protesters using guns with [[rubber bullet]]s or [[plastic bullet]]s.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/plastic+bullet http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/plastic+bullet] "A solid PVC cylinder, 10 cm long and 38 mm in diameter, fired by police or military forces to regain control in riots."</ref> [[Tear gas]], which was developed by the [[United States Army]] for [[riot control]] in 1919, was widely used against protesters in the 2000s. The use of tear gas in [[war]]fare is prohibited by various international treaties<ref>e.g. the [[Geneva Protocol]] of 1925: 'Prohibited the use of "asphyxiating gas, or any other kind of gas, liquids, substances or similar materials"'</ref> that most states have signed; however, its law enforcement or [[military]] use for [[domestic policy|domestic]] or non-[[combat]] situations is permitted.
Concerns about the militarization of police have been raised by both ends of the political spectrum in the [[United States]], with both the right-of-center/libertarian [[Cato Institute]] and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] voicing criticisms of the practice. The [[Fraternal Order of Police]] has spoken out in favor of equipping law enforcement officers with military equipment, on the grounds that it increases the officers' safety and enables them to protect members of the public and other [[first responder]]s (e.g., [[firefighter]]s and [[emergency medical services]] personnel). However, a 2017 study showed that police forces which received military equipment were more likely to have violent encounters with the public, regardless of local crime rates.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/06/30/does-military-equipment-lead-police-officers-to-be-more-violent-we-did-the-research/| author=Ryan Welch and Jack Mewhirter| title=Does military equipment lead police officers to be more violent? We did the research.| publisher=The Washington Post| date=June 30, 2017}}</ref>
==Canada== [[File:Riot_Police_at_Richmond_and_Spadina_(4740549169).jpg|thumb|150px|left|A [[Barrie Police Service|Barrie Police officer]] in full [[Riot control|riot gear]] at the [[2010 G20 Toronto summit protests]] ]] Canadian legal expert Michael Spratt wrote, "... there's no question that Canadian police sometimes look more like post-apocalyptic military mercenaries than protectors of the peace. Our police services have been acquiring more and more military toys — a dangerous trend that's gotten little in the way of critical analysis in the mainstream media."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ipolitics.ca/2014/08/15/the-creeping-militarization-of-the-police/| author=Michael Spratt| title=The creeping militarization of the police| publisher=iPolitics| date=August 15, 2014}}</ref> Growing numbers of [[Canada|Canadian]] police agencies have acquired armored vehicles in recent years.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/08/21/we-call-it-a-rescue-vehicle-growing-number-of-canadian-police-forces-bulking-up-with-armoured-vehicles/| author=Douglas Quan| title='We call it a rescue vehicle': Growing number of Canadian police forces bulking up with armoured vehicles| work=National Post| date=August 21, 2014}}</ref> In 2010 the Ottawa Police Service bought a [[Lenco BearCat|Lenco G3 BearCat]] armored personnel carrier for $340,000, which has "half-inch-thick military steel armoured bodywork, .50 caliber-rated ballistic glass, blast-resistant floors, custom-designed gun ports and... a roof turret."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelspratt.com/law-blog/police-militarization|title=Canadian Police Militarization|work=Michael Spratt}}</ref> [[Image:Nash Bearcat.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Lenco BearCat Armored Personnel Carrier]] The [[2010 G-20 Toronto summit protests|G20 protests]] in Toronto in 2010 showed that the militarization of protest policing is not only occurring in the United States. Police in Toronto used a sound cannon, or [[Long Range Acoustic Device]] (LRAD) -- a [[weapon]] that was developed for use in conflicts in the Middle East, as well as barricades, pre-emptive arrests and riot units.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rabble.ca/blogs/bloggers/views-expressed/2014/09/canadian-police-agencies-innovators-militarization|title=Canadian police agencies: Innovators in militarization?|work=rabble.ca}}</ref> According to Kevin Walby, an assistant professor of criminal justice at the [[University of Winnipeg]], "the more interesting aspect of the militarization of the police is actually on the strategy side"; police are "increasingly training with military-style tacticians, especially when it comes to situations like [[crowd control]] and, increasingly, [[surveillance]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://o.canada.com/news/police-militarization-is-already-in-canada-as-surveillance-on-the-rise | author=Ashley Csanady| title=Police militarization is already in Canada as surveillance on the rise| publisher=Canada.com| date=August 15, 2014}}</ref>
On June 3, 2015 it was reported that "RCMP officers have started openly carrying [[MP5]] submachine guns on [[Parliament Hill]] as part of a visible increase to Parliament Hill security following last [[2014 shootings at Parliament Hill, Ottawa|October's terrorist attack]]" in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/rcmp-brings-out-the-big-guns-to-the-dismay-of-some|title=Mounties now toting submachine guns for Hill security|author=Lee Berthiaume, Ottawa Citizen More Lee Berthiaume, Ottawa Citizen|work=Ottawa Citizen}}</ref> Conservative senator [[Vern White]], a former RCMP officer and a former Ottawa police chief states that "...some RCMP officers guarding Parliament Hill against potential terrorist attacks should be armed with rifles similar to those carried by Canadian troops in Afghanistan [,]" the "...more powerful Colt [[C8 carbine|C8]] [which is] popular with police tactical teams and Canadian and other NATO alliance troops." White argues that the C8 carbines would give officers a much longer shooting range than the short-barreled [[MP5|MP5 submachine guns]]. "The RCMP is issuing more than 2,200 C8 carbines to its officers [,]" but the RCMP has not indicated whether the C8s will be issued to Parliament Hill officers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/boost-firepower-of-rcmp-guards-on-parliament-hill-says-senator|title=Boost firepower of Mounties guarding Parliament Hill, says senator|author=David Pugliese, Ottawa Citizen More David Pugliese, Ottawa Citizen|work=Ottawa Citizen}}</ref>
==Brazil== In 2013 "...Brazil saw countrywide demonstrations protesting a lack of basic services while the country was spending billions on the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] and the [[2016 Summer Olympics|Olympics]]. The unprepared and overreacting police forces responded in a way that shocked the largely middle-class protesters. The police, using "non-lethal" weapons like pepper spray and rubber bullets while dressed from head to toe in ninja-like full battle gear, indiscriminately arrested both violent "[[black bloc]]" demonstrators, known for their confrontational tactics and anarchist views, along with non-violent protestors marching peacefully." As a result, "...calls for de-militarization of the police—from social movements, non-governmental organizations, and even segments of the police itself—became widespread and remain one of the legacies of the World Cup." The Brazilian "...Military Police today, while not officially a wing of the Armed Forces, remains an institution with a strict military hierarchy, training that retains a military ideology, and practices that frequently resemble occupying forces conquering enemy territories."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wola.org/commentary/police_militarization_similarities_between_ferguson_and_brazil|title=Police Militarization: Similarities Between Ferguson and Brazil|publisher=wola.org}}</ref> The units that responded to the protests were Shock Police, units specialized in [[riot control]]. The Military Police is an ancillary and reserve force of the Army, under the General Inspectorate of Military Police, being that a part of Land Operations Command. But, in time of peace, the state governor act as commander-in-chief of the Police and Firefighting Corps, according to the [[Constitution of Brazil]], article 144, 6th paragraph, where it is said that the "Military Police and Firefighter Corps, ancillary and reserve forces of the Army, subordinate themselves, with the Civil Police, to the state and Federal District governors."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.coter.eb.mil.br/igpm/index.php/2013-03-19-15-57-34|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317105455/http://www.coter.eb.mil.br/igpm/index.php/2013-03-19-15-57-34|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-17|title=Legislação|website=www.coter.eb.mil.br|language=pt-br|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref>
==Colombia== "Since 1999, an eight-billion-dollar programme in [[Colombia]] has seen "the mass deployment of military troops and militarized police forces to both interdict illegal drugs and counter left-wing guerrilla groups". This assistance "promote[s] militarization to address organized crime".<ref name="ipsnews.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2014/08/despite-current-debate-police-militarisation-goes-beyond-u-s-borders/|title=Despite Current Debate, Police Militarisation Goes Beyond U.S. Borders|publisher=ipsnews.net}}</ref> Due to these U.S. policies, "civilian forces... have increasingly received military training, leading to concerns over human rights violations and excessive use of force, as well as a lack of knowledge over how to deal with local protests – concerns startlingly similar to those now coming out of Ferguson, Missouri."<ref name="ipsnews.net"/>
==Germany== In 2016, the German police introduced a "new special unit, BFE+", which is designed to "counter terror attacks." <ref name="dw.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/germanys-new-anti-terror-units-a-paramilitary-excess/a-19010175|title=Germany's new anti-terror units: A paramilitary excess? - Germany - DW - 28.01.2016|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM}}</ref> Criminologist Rafael Behr states that the new BFE+ "mainly serves as a psychological reassurance for the public", serving as a "symbolic" effort and a functional effort.<ref name="dw.com"/> The functional aspect is that with the BFE+, the government can use armed forces with military weapons inside Germany, an act that is "currently banned by the German constitution".<ref name="dw.com"/> The 250 person BFE+ will be added to the existing [[GSG-9]] unit. Behr states that the BFE+ will be able to "launch large-scale manhunts", using an "end of the policing spectrum" which "borders on war-like or military action."<ref name="dw.com"/>
==Mexico== [[Mexico|Mexico's]] new national police force, the Gendarmería, is partially staffed with active duty soldiers, part of a longstanding trend towards militarization of the country's [[Federal Police (Mexico)|Federal Police]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.wola.org/commentary/mexico_s_new_military_police_force_the_continued_militarization_of_public_security_in_mex| author=Maureen Meyer| title=Mexico's New Military Police Force: The Continued Militarization of Public Security in Mexico| publisher=Washington Office on Latin America| date=March 13, 2013}}</ref>
==Indonesia== [[File:Pelopor brimob.png|thumb|300px|Brimob troops of the [[Indonesian National Police]]]] The '''[[Mobile Brigade Corps (Brimob)]]''' is an [[Indonesia]]n militarized police force (Paramilitary) which are often deployed for Riot control, SWAT operations, anti-terror, domestic guerrilla warfare, domestic civil hostage rescue, search and rescue, and armed conflict management especially in areas with domestic conflict, such as in [[Papua (province)|Papua]] and [[Poso]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.american.edu/sis/news/20140916-The-Militarization-of-Police-at-Home-and-Abroad.cfm|title=The Militarization of Police at Home and Abroad|work=american.edu}}</ref> It usually conducts join operations with the [[Indonesian Army|TNI]].
==United States{{anchor|United States}}==
===History===
====19th Century==== Following the [[Reconstruction Era]] (1865–1877) in the aftermath of the [[American Civil War]] (1861–1865), [[United States Congress|Congress]] passed the 1878 [[Posse Comitatus Act]], in response to the allegation of [[civil liberties]] abuse under [[military occupation]] of the former [[Confederacy (American Civil War)|Confederate States]] by members of the [[United States Armed Forces|United States military]] during Reconstruction. Still in force, the law prohibits the [[United States Army]] and the [[United States Air Force]] (as amended in 1956) for being used as [[domestic policy|domestic]] [[law enforcement]] except when authorized by the [[President of the United States|President]] under certain circumstances; similar limitation also applies to the [[United States Marine Corps]] and the [[United States Navy]] by [[United States Department of the Navy|Department of the Navy]] policy. The Act does not apply to the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] and [[state defense force]]s while under the authority of their respective [[Governor (United States)|state governors]] nor the [[United States Coast Guard]], which is both an [[armed service]] and a [[maritime law enforcement]] agency and is not under authority of the [[United States Department of Defense]] (which was formed in 1947 out of the [[United States Department of War]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usacac.army.mil/cac2/call/docs/10-16/ch_12.asp|title=Domestic Operational Law: The Posse Comitatus Act and Homeland Security|website=army.mil}}</ref><ref>[http://www.hsdl.org/?view&did=706794 THE POSSE COMITATUS ACT: A HINDRANCE TO NATIONAL SECURITY IN NEED OF A CHANGE]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pubs/parameters/Articles/04autumn/felicett.pdf|title=The Posse Comitatus Act: Liberation from the Lawyers|website=army.mil}}</ref> After the law was passed, it allowed [[U.S. state|state]] and [[Local government in the United States|local authorities]] to regain control of their affairs, with their police departments typically equipped with [[handguns]], [[shotguns]], and [[Baton (law enforcement)|batons]], which were suitable for law enforcement purposes.
====20th Century==== [[File:Thompsonad1sm.jpg|thumb|upright|The "Anti-Bandit Gun": a 1920s advertisement of the [[Thompson submachine gun|Thompson M1921]] for United States [[Police|law enforcement]] forces]] Throughout the 20th century, the United States has faced large and heavily armed [[criminal organizations]], in which law enforcement officers were clearly outperformed. In the 1920s during the [[Prohibition Era]] and in the early 1930s during the [[Great Depression]], criminal syndicates and individual bank robbers such as [[John Dillinger]] and [[Bonnie and Clyde]] were frequently armed with [[Thompson submachine gun]]s and [[Browning Automatic Rifles]].<ref>Ray Bearse, "The Thompson Submachine Gun: Weapon of War and Peace", in Murtz, ''Gun Digest Treasury'' (DBI Books, 1994), p.210 {{ISBN|0873491564}}</ref> The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI), as well as police departments in cities such as [[Kansas City, Missouri]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/crime/article1337845.html|title=Police armored vehicles have long history|work=kansascity}}</ref> and [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kenoshapolice.com/history-department|title=History of Department|work=Kenosha Police Department}}</ref> began deploying automatic weapons, including the Thompson submachine gun, and armored cars in the 1920s and 1930s. [[File:Firearms practice, 1936.jpg|thumb|left|200px|An FBI officer firing a [[Browning Automatic Rifle]] in 1936.]]
[[George Fletcher Chandler]], a veteran of the [[Pancho Villa Expedition]] and the first Superintendent of the [[New York State Police]], was an early advocate of law enforcement officers wearing their weapons exposed on the outside of their uniforms.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Miller|first1=Wilbur R.|title=The Social History of Crime and Punishment in America: An Encyclopedia|date=2012|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9781412988766|page=1230|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tYME6Z35nyAC&pg=PA1230&dq=george+fletcher+chandler&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjiz_zxr6_TAhVD64MKHUkkChwQ6AEIVjAJ#v=onepage&q=george%20fletcher%20chandler&f=false|accessdate=19 April 2017|language=en}}</ref>
During [[Social issues of the 1920s in the United States|the late 1920s through the early 1930s]], gunmen from criminal gangs in the United States began wearing [[bulletproof vest]]s made from thick layers of cotton padding and cloth. These early vests could absorb the impact of handgun rounds such as [[.22 Long Rifle]], [[.25 ACP]], [[.32 S&W Long]], [[.32 S&W]], [[.380 ACP]], [[.38 Special]] and [[.45 ACP]] traveling at speeds of up to {{convert|300|m/s|abbr=on}}. To overcome these vests, law enforcement agents such as the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] began using the newer and more powerful [[.38 Super]], and later the [[.357 Magnum]] cartridge.
Experts believes that police militarization was escalated in the 1950s and 1960s, an era in which [[race riot]]s were common in many U.S. cities. Some believe that the seeming success of officers armed with military-style weapons and deployed to curtail the 1965 [[Watts Riots]], a six-day race riot sparked by conflicts with the [[Los Angeles Police Department]] (LAPD) that killed 34 people, gave way to the trend of arming and equipping law enforcement officers with battlefield weapons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/police-militarization-history-stretches-back-civil-rights-movement-photos-1926956|title=Police Militarization History Stretches Back To Civil Rights Movement [PHOTOS]|author=Aaron Morrison|date=May 18, 2015|work=International Business Times}}</ref> Joy Rohde, a professor at the [[University of Michigan]]'s [[Ford School of Public Policy]], has published research indicating that "militarization is a mindset...is a tendency to see the world through the lens of national security, a tendency to exaggerate existing threats." Rohde traces "the origins of modern militarized policing" to the [[Cold War]]-era [[anti-communist]] paranoia, and the idea that domestic civil rights activists were similar to foreign enemies, as manifested in activities such as the CIA's [[Operation CHAOS]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.businessinsider.com/police-militarization-is-a-relic-of-cold-war-paranoia-2016-8| author=Joy Rohde| title=Police militarization is a relic of Cold War paranoia| publisher=Business Insider| date=August 7, 2016}}</ref>
Things have changed over the last 100 years and due to the rise of acts of terrorism and the easy access to high-powered weapons; special weapons and tactics teams have been implemented and are being utilized across the nation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Clark|first=J|date=2000|title=Training SWAT teams: Implications for improving tactical units.|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047235200000556|journal=Journal of Criminal Justice|doi=10.1016/S0047-2352(00)00055-6|pmid=|access-date=|volume=28|pages=407–413}}</ref> The 1960s to 1990s, encounters with the sophisticated weapons of narcotics trafficking groups such as the [[Medellín Cartel]] and street gangs such as the [[Gangster Disciples]], with organized, violent left-wing protesters at such events as the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]] in [[Chicago]] and the 1999 [[WTO Ministerial Conference of 1999 protest activity|WTO Conference]] in [[Seattle]],<ref name="ew1">{{Cite news|first = Kera|last = Abraham|title = Flames of Dissent|newspaper = Eugene Weekly|date = November 22, 2006|url = http://www.eugeneweekly.com/2006/11/22/coverstory.html|accessdate = June 10, 2007}}</ref> with [[urban riots]] such as the 1965 Watts riots in [[Los Angeles]] and the [[1967 Detroit Riot]] in [[Detroit]] led law enforcement to reconsider their standard [[side arm]]s. As well, law enforcement experience with arsonists such as [[Earth Liberation Front]] (ELF),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2003719703_ecosentence24m.html|title=Earth Liberation Front arsonist sentenced to 13 years|date=May 24, 2007|work=The Seattle Times}}</ref><ref name="reg2007">{{Cite news|first= Bill|last= Bishop|title= Local unrest followed cycle of social movements|date= July 1, 2007|url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/registerguard/access/1305884951.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jul+1%2C+2007&author=The+Register-Guard&pub=The+Register+-+Guard&edition=&startpage=A.1&desc=Local+unrest+followed+cycle+of+social+movements|work = The Register-Guard|accessdate= September 6, 2007|page=A1}}</ref> with mass [[shooting]]s and/or [[shootout]]s such as the 1984 [[San Ysidro McDonald's massacre|McDonald's massacre]] in [[San Ysidro]] and the [[1986 FBI Miami shootout|1986 shootout]] between eight FBI agents and two serial [[bank robbers]] in [[Miami]] (in which the agents were out-gunned by the robbers) and with [[explosive devices]] used by the [[Weather Underground]], [[Timothy McVeigh]], and [[Ted Kaczynski]] (the "Unabomber"), highlighted the inadequacy of many law enforcement agencies' weapons and tactics.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
Researchers David N. Falcone, Edward L. Wells, and Ralph A. Weisheit describe a historical separation of police models between small towns and larger cities, which tended to function differently with separate hierarchical systems supporting each.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Falcone | first1 = David N. | last2 = Wells | first2 = Edward L. | last3 = Weisheit | first3 = Ralph A. | year = 2002 | title = The Small-Town Police Department | url = | journal = Policing | volume = 25 | issue = 2| pages = 371–85 | doi=10.1108/13639510210429419}}</ref> The militarization of both rural and urban law enforcement has been attributed to the United States' involvement in wars during the 20th century, and to increasingly frequent encounters with violent protesters and criminals with automatic weapons, explosives, and body armor, although some attribute the militarization to the more recent campaigns known as the [[War on Drugs]] and the [[War on Terror]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gregory | first1 = Anthony | year = 2014 | title = Rise of the Warrior Cop: The Militarization of America's Police Forces | url = | journal = The Independent Review | volume = 19 | issue = 2| pages = 271–75 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kraska | first1 = Peter B | year = 1999 | title = Militarizing Criminal Justice: Exploring the Possibilities | url = | journal = The Journal of Political and Military Sociology | volume = 27 | issue = 2| pages = 205–15 }}</ref> Historian [[Charles A. Beard]] argues that cultural change during the Great Depression encouraged the militarization of law enforcement,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kohn | first1 = Richard H | year = 2008 | title = The Danger of Militarization in an Endless 'War' on Terrorism | url = | journal = The Journal of Military History | volume = 73 | issue = 1| pages = 177–208 | doi=10.1353/jmh.0.0216}}</ref> whereas Harwood argues that the creation of SWAT teams and tactical units within law enforcement during the 1960s began such trend.
[[File:Special response vehicle from Homeland Security during OSI Det. 340's law enforcement day.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[United States Department of Homeland Security|Homeland Security]] armored vehicle]] The 1981 [[Military Cooperation with Civilian Law Enforcement Agencies Act]] allows the U.S. military to cooperate with domestic and foreign law enforcement agencies. Operations in support of law enforcement include assistance in counter-drug operations, assistance for civil disturbances, special security operations, [[counter-terrorism]], explosive ordnance disposal (EOD), and similar activities. Constitutional and statutory restrictions and corresponding directives and regulations limit the type of support provided in this area. This allows the U.S. military to give law enforcement agencies access to [[List of United States military bases|its military bases]] and [[Equipment of the United States Armed Forces|its military equipment]].<ref name=balko>{{cite news|last1=Balko|first1=Radley|title=A Decade After 9/11, Police Departments Are Increasingly Militarized|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/12/police-militarization-9-11-september-11_n_955508.html|accessdate=November 29, 2014|work=The Huffington Post|date=September 11, 2011}}</ref> The legislation was promoted during the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan]] in the context of the [[War on drugs]], and is considered a part of a general trend towards the militarization of police.<ref name=balko /> The Act is cited in the 1992 essay ''[[The Origins of the American Military Coup of 2012]]'' as having set a precedent that the author, a [[United States Air Force]] officer, considered dangerous.
The 1997 [[North Hollywood shootout]] had a profound effect on law enforcement agencies. Local patrol officers at the time were typically armed with their standard issue [[9×19mm]] or [[.38 Special]] pistols, with some having a [[gauge (bore diameter)|12-gauge]] shotgun available in their cars. The North Hollywood bank robbers carried fully automatic [[AK-47]]-style weapons with high capacity [[drum magazine]]s and ammunition capable of penetrating vehicles and police Kevlar vests. With these weapons, two bank robbers fired approximately 1,100 rounds at officers and civilians before being killed. The robbers wore [[ballistic vest|body armor]] which successfully protected them from bullets and shotgun pellets fired by the responding patrolmen. Police noted that the service pistols carried by the first responding officers had insufficient range and relatively poor accuracy, although a SWAT team eventually arrived with sufficient firepower.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} The ineffectiveness of the standard police patrol pistols and shotguns in penetrating the robbers' body armor led to a trend in the United States toward arming selected police officers, not just SWAT teams, with heavier firepower such as semi-automatic [[5.56×45mm NATO]] [[AR-15]] type rifles.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} SWAT teams, whose close quarters battle weaponry usually consisted of [[submachine gun]]s that fired pistol cartridges such as the [[Heckler & Koch MP5]], began supplementing them with AR-15 type rifles and carbines.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
[[File:Police State Pittsburgh G20.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Riot police at 2009 G20 meeting in Pittsburgh]]
Seven months after the incident, the Department of Defense gave 600 surplus [[M16 rifle|M16s]] to the LAPD, which were issued to each patrol sergeant;<ref>LAPD gets M16s.</ref><ref>LAPD gets M16s; LAPD museum showcases department's good, bad, ugly.</ref> LAPD patrol vehicles now carry AR-15s as standard issue, with bullet-resistant [[Kevlar]] plating in their doors as well.<ref>Prengaman, 2.</ref>{{full citation needed|date=February 2015}} As a result of this incident, the LAPD authorized its officers to carry .45 ACP caliber semiautomatic pistols as duty sidearms, specifically the [[Smith & Wesson Model 4506|Smith & Wesson Models 4506 and 4566]]. Prior to 1997, only LAPD SWAT officers were authorized to carry .45 ACP caliber pistols, specifically the Model 1911A1 .45 ACP semiautomatic pistol.<ref>{{cite web |title=LAPD Swat |url=http://www.shootingtimes.com/2011/01/03/handgun_reviews_st_0212_lapd/|publisher=Shootingtimes.com|accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref> [[File:A police officer peers through the telescope sight of an M4 carbine as he breaches into the Live Fire Shoot House at the Camp Atterbury Joint Maneuver Training Center in Edinburgh, Indiana, May 13, 2010 100513-A-MG787-323.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A U.S. police officer armed with a holographic sight-equipped [[M4 carbine]] rifle during a training exercise]] The [[1033 program]] was created by the National Defense Authorization Act of Fiscal Year 1997 as part of the [[DLA Disposition Services|U.S. Government's Defense Logistics Agency Disposition Services]] (DLA) to transfer excess military equipment to law enforcement agencies.<ref name=LESO>{{cite web|title=The Law Enforcement Support Office |url=http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/pages/default.aspx |website=Defense Logistics Agency |publisher=United States Government |accessdate=August 16, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209035113/http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Pages/default.aspx |archivedate=December 9, 2014 |df= }}</ref> {{As of|2014}}, 8,000 local law enforcement agencies participate in the reutilization program that has transferred $5.1 billion in military hardware from the [[United States Department of Defense]] to local American law enforcement agencies since 1997.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} Police departments have obtained surplus aircraft, [[bayonets]], tactical armored vehicles, weapons, including grenade launchers, and [[watercraft]].{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
====21st Century==== Under the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth Amendment]], law enforcement officers must receive written permission from a court of law, or otherwise qualified [[magistrate]], to lawfully search and seize evidence while investigating criminal activity. Following the [[September 11 attacks]], the 2001 [[Patriot Act]] gave law enforcement officers permission to search a home or business without the owner's or the occupant's consent or knowledge, amongst other provisions, if terrorist activities were suspected. The Act was criticized for its perceived violation of civil liberties and has generated a great deal of controversy since its enactment. In ''[[United States v. Antoine Jones]]'', the court found that increased monitoring of suspects caused by the Patriot Act directly put the suspects' [[Constitutional right#United States|constitutional rights]] in jeopardy. For a time, the Act allowed for agents to undertake "sneak and peek" searches. Critics such as the ACLU strongly criticized the law for violating the Fourth Amendment.<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.aclu.org/safefree/patriot/16745prs20030903.html|title=Uncle Sam Asks: "What the hell is going on here?" in New ACLU Print and Radio Advertisements|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|date=September 10, 2003}}</ref><ref name="FactCheckOnACLUAdv">{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/aclu_ad_on_sneak-and-peek_searches_overblown.html|title=ACLU Ad On "Sneak-and-Peek" Searches: Overblown|publisher=FactCheck.org|date=September 21, 2004|postscript=<!--None-->|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714102208/http://www.factcheck.org/aclu_ad_on_sneak-and-peek_searches_overblown.html|archivedate=July 14, 2007|df=}}</ref>
On May 18, 2015, President [[Barack Obama]] announced limits on the types of military equipment which can be transferred to police departments and the implementation of training programs to assure the appropriate use of other items. The military can no longer transfer some weapons, such as grenade launchers, weaponized vehicles, and bayonets to police.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://news.vice.com/article/the-military-equipment-gravy-train-is-ending-for-local-police-departments| author=Colleen Curry| title=The Military Equipment Gravy Train Is Ending for Local Police Departments| publisher=Vice| date=May 18, 2015}}</ref> Obama stated that "We've seen how militarized gear can sometimes give people a feeling like it's an [[military occupation|occupying force]] as opposed to a force that's part of the community that's protecting them and serving them,...So we're going to prohibit equipment made for the battlefield that is not appropriate for local police departments."<ref name="politico.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/white-house-limiting-military-equipment-for-police-118041.html|title=Police union accuses White House of politicizing cop safety|work=POLITICO}}</ref>
In response to Obama's announcement, the United States' largest police union, the [[Fraternal Order of Police]], reacted negatively, pledging to push back against the new restrictions, and accusing the administration of politicizing officers' safety.<ref name="politico.com"/> The executive director of the FOP, James Pasco, stated that his group "...(would) be at (their) most aggressive in asserting the need for officer safety and officer rights in any police changes that are to be effected", and objected to a requirement that would require police departments to obtain permission from city governments to acquire certain equipment, including riot batons, helmets and shields, through federal programs.<ref name="politico.com"/> Pasco stated "We need to only look back to [[2015 Baltimore protests|Baltimore]] (the location of the 2015 protests following the [[death of Freddie Gray]]) to see what happens when officers are sent out ill-equipped in a disturbance situation...[;] Because you don't like the optics (of militarization), you can't send police officers out to be hurt or killed."<ref name="politico.com"/>
In July 2016, the Obama Administration announced that it would revisit the 2015 ban on some types of military equipment for police forces, and begin a process of case-by-case review.<ref name=td20160722>{{cite news |url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20160722/07570135041/administrations-one-year-experimentation-with-reining-police-militarization-apparently-over.shtml |title=Administration's One-Year Experimentation With Reining In Police Militarization Apparently Over |work=TechDirt |date=2016-07-22 |accessdate=2016-07-30 }}</ref>
On August 28, 2017 U.S. Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] announced the lifting of restrictions on the transfer of military equipment to law enforcement agencies.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/28/546743742/trump-administration-lifts-limits-on-military-hardware-for-police| author=Ryan Lucas| title=Trump Administration Lifts Limits On Military Hardware For Police| publisher=NPR| date=August 28, 2017}}</ref> Sessions said during his announcement that the [[Donald Trump|Trump]] administration would not "put superficial concerns above public safety".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/sessions-announces-end-to-obama-era-ban-on-surplus-military-equipment-for-police/| author=Emily Tillett| title=Sessions announces end to Obama-era ban on surplus military equipment for police| publisher=CBS News| date=August 28, 2017}}</ref>
====="War on Police"{{anchor|Allegations_of_.22war_on_police.22|Allegations_of_"war_on_police"}}===== Some prominent Americans have argued that police militarization is required to respond to an alleged "war on police" that exists in the U.S.: Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick stated "There's A War On Cops", New York Police Chief Bratton warned of a "war on cops" and similar statements have been made by [[Donald Trump]], [[Ted Cruz]], and [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]].<ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-watch/wp/2015/09/10/once-again-there-is-no-war-on-cops-and-those-who-claim-otherwise-are-playing-a-dangerous-game/ | title=Once again: There is no 'war on cops.' And those who claim otherwise are playing a dangerous game. | last=Balko | first=Radley | date=10 September 2015 | publisher= | via=washingtonpost.com | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151105045458/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-watch/wp/2015/09/10/once-again-there-is-no-war-on-cops-and-those-who-claim-otherwise-are-playing-a-dangerous-game/ | archive-date=2015-11-05 | dead-url=no }}</ref> [[Radley Balko]] calls these claims "fact-free [[fear mongering]]"; he states that "...2015 is on pace to see 35 felonious killings of police officers. If that pace holds, this year would end with the second lowest number of murdered cops in decades." as well as "...not only are fewer people killing police officers, fewer people are trying to harm them."<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
===Notable incidents=== [[File:Mountcarmelfire04-19-93-n.jpg|thumb|right|305px|The [[Mount Carmel Center]] engulfed in flames during the [[Waco siege|siege of the Branch Davidian community]] in [[Waco]], [[Texas]] on April 19, 1993]]
====MOVE bombing==== On Monday, May 13, 1985, Philadelphia police attempted to clear a building occupied by [[MOVE]] [[Black theology|black liberation]] activists and execute arrest warrants.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shapiro|first1=Michael J|title=The Time of the City: Politics, Philosophy and Genre|date=June 17, 2010|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136977879|page=108}}</ref> This led to an armed standoff with police,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-05-11-philadelphia-bombing_x.htm| author=Martha T. Moore| title=1985 bombing in Philadelphia still unsettled| publisher=USA Today| date=May 11, 2005}}</ref> who lobbed [[tear gas]] canisters at the building. The police said that MOVE members fired at them; a gunfight with [[Semi-automatic firearm|semi-automatic]] and [[automatic firearm]]s ensued. Commissioner Sambor ordered that the compound be bombed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevens|first=William K.|title=Police Drop Bomb on Radicals' Home in Philadelphia|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/14/us/police-drop-bomb-on-radicals-home-in-philadelphia.html?pagewanted=all|publisher=New York Times|date=14 May 1985}}</ref> From a Pennsylvania State Police helicopter, Philadelphia Police Lt. Frank Powell proceeded to drop two one-pound bombs (which the police referred to as "entry devices") made of FBI-supplied [[water gel explosive]], a [[dynamite]] substitute, targeting a fortified, bunker-like cubicle on the roof of the house.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,141842,00.html |author=Frank Trippett| title=It Looks Just Like a War Zone |publisher=TIME |date=June 24, 2001}}</ref>
The resulting explosions ignited a fire which spread and eventually destroyed approximately 65 nearby houses.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.democracynow.org/2010/5/13/25_years_ago_philadelphia_police_bombs| title=25 Years Ago: Philadelphia Police Bombs MOVE Headquarters Killing 11, Destroying 65 Homes| publisher=Democracy Now!| date=May 13, 2010}}</ref> Eleven people (John Africa, five other adults, and five children aged 7 to 13) died in the resulting fire, and more than 250 people in the neighborhood were left homeless.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/04/us/grand-jury-clears-everyone-in-fatal-philadelphia-siege.html| author=WILLIAM K. STEVENS| title=Grand Jury Clears Everyone In Fatal Philadelphia Siege| publisher=New York Times| date=May 4, 1988}}</ref> Ramona Africa, one of the two survivors, said that police fired at those trying to escape.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4651126 |title=Philadelphia MOVE Bombing Still Haunts Survivors |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
====Ruby Ridge==== In 1992, there was a deadly confrontation and a 12-day [[siege]] at [[Ruby Ridge]] in [[northern Idaho]] between [[Randy Weaver]], his family and his friend Kevin Harris, and agents of the [[United States Marshals Service]] (USMS) and [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI). USMS and FBI agents were armed with M16s and sniper rifles, and they used an armored personnel carrier. It resulted in the deaths of two Weaver's son Sammy, his wife Vicki, and Deputy U.S. Marshal William Francis Degan. At the subsequent federal criminal trial of Weaver and Harris, Weaver's attorney [[Gerry Spence]] made accusations of "criminal wrongdoing" against every agency involved in the incident: the FBI, USMS, the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]] (BATFE), and the [[United States Attorney's Office]] (USAO) for Idaho. At the completion of the trial, the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]]'s [[Office of Professional Responsibility]] formed a Ruby Ridge Task Force to investigate Spence's charges. The 1994 Task Force report was released in redacted form by Lexis Counsel Connect and raised questions about the conduct and policy of all the agencies. Public outcry over Ruby Ridge led to the [[United States Senate|Senate]] Subcommittee on Terrorism, Technology and Government Information holding 14 days of hearings and issuing a report calling for reforms in [[Federal law enforcement in the United States|federal law enforcement]] to prevent a repeat of Ruby Ridge and to restore public confidence in federal law enforcement.
====Branch Davidian siege==== In 1993, FBI and BATFE agents used armored vehicles and tanks and attack helicopters during the [[Waco siege|siege of the Branch Davidian community]] in [[Waco]], [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/what-really-happened-at-waco/| title=What Really Happened At Waco| publisher=60 Minutes/CBS News| date=January 25, 2000}}</ref> The FBI's arms included [[.50 caliber]] (12.7 mm) rifles and [[M728 Combat Engineer Vehicle]]s, which are based on an [[M60 Patton|M60A1 Patton]] [[main battle tank]] chassis.<ref name="PMania">{{cite web|url=http://www.patton-mania.com/M60_Patton/m60_patton.html|title=Development and History of the M60 tank: M728 CEV|publisher=Patton Mania|accessdate=June 21, 2011}}</ref> The FBI also launched {{convert|40|mm|adj=on}} CS grenade fire from [[M79 grenade launcher]]s and fired two military M651 rounds at the Branch Davidian site. 40mm munitions recovered by the Texas Rangers at Waco included dozens of plastic Ferret Model SGA-400 Liquid CS rounds, two metal M651 military pyrotechnic tear gas rounds, two metal NICO Pyrotechnik Sound & Flash grenades, and parachute illumination flares.<ref>Texas Rangers, Department of Public Safety, [http://www.txdps.state.tx.us/director_staff/public_information/branch_davidian/indexfirst.htm Branch Davidian Evidence], Investigative Report No. 1, September 1999; Investigative Report No. 2, January 2000 (PDFs available at Texas Rangers website). The Army considers the M651 a pyrotechnic device and that it is known to cause fires.</ref> The Army Tech Manual for the M651 warns that it can penetrate 3/4" plywood at 200 meters and the "projectile may explode upon target impact."
====Other events==== =====2005-2009===== In 2005, the [[Maryland State Police]] (MSP) began entering the names and personal information of death penalty opponents and anti-war protesters into a database used to track terrorists.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/07/AR2008100703245.html | author=Lisa Rein | title=Md. Police Put Activists' Names On Terror Lists | work=The Washington Post | date=October 8, 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100305004351/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/10/07/AR2008100703245.html | archive-date=2010-03-05 | dead-url=no }}</ref>
In the aftermath of [[Effects of Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans|Hurricane Katrina]] in [[New Orleans]] in 2005, employees of the private security firm [[Blackwater (company)|Blackwater]] patrolled the city with automatic weapons. "When asked what authority they were operating under," journalist Jeremy Scahill reported, "one guy said, 'We're on contract with the Department of Homeland Security.'" Local news station [[WDSU]] mentioned reports of police officers claiming to have [[summary execution|summarily executed]] looters.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2009/08/secret-history-hurricane-katrina| author=James Ridgeway| title=The Secret History of Hurricane Katrina| work=Mother Jones| date=August 28, 2009}}</ref>
On August 25, 2008, the [[Denver Police Department]] (DPD) were accused of making mass, indiscriminate arrests of almost 100 protesters at the Democratic National Convention. In 2011, the city of [[Denver, Colorado]] agreed to pay a $200,000 settlement and to improve its crowd control training and policies.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.denverpost.com/2011/08/16/denver-settles-suit-linked-to-2008-democratic-national-convention/ | title=Denver settles suit linked to 2008 Democratic National Convention | work=The Denver Post | date=August 16, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180214012254/https://www.denverpost.com/2011/08/16/denver-settles-suit-linked-to-2008-democratic-national-convention/ | archive-date=2018-02-14 | dead-url=no }}</ref>
=====2010-2014===== In February 2010, the [[Minneapolis Police Department]] (MPD) raided the apartment of Rickia Russell, breaching the door and throwing in a [[flashbang grenade]], as part of a search for drugs. At the time, Russell was eating dinner with her boyfriend and the exploding grenade gave her burns to her head and calves. No drugs were found in Russell's apartment and the Minneapolis City Council agreed to pay $1 million in damages.<ref name="Hennessey">{{cite web|last=Hennessey |first=Virginia|url=http://www.montereyherald.com/article/ZZ/20130819/NEWS/130818031 |title=Monterey County agrees to pay $2.6 million in 'flash-bang' death of Greenfield man |work=Monterey Herald |date=August 19, 2013 |accessdate=February 27, 2014}}</ref> In January 2011, Rogelio Serrato in [[Greenfield, California|Greenfield]], [[California]], died of [[smoke inhalation]] after a flashbang grenade launched by the SWAT team of the Greenfield Police Department (GPD) ignited a fire in his home.<ref name="Hennessey"/>
In May 2011, the [[Pima County]] Sheriff's department killed Marine and Iraq war veteran [[Jose Guerena shooting|Jose Guerena]], when they entered his home while serving a search warrant related to a marijuana smuggling investigation. They fired 71 shots into his home, while his wife and 4-year-old child were inside, and found no drugs nor anything illegal. The departments involved paid a $3.4 million settlement.<ref name=Wired_1>{{cite news | title=Drug Raid Turns Ugly as SWAT guns down Marine vet | work=Wired.com | url=https://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/05/drug-raid-turns-ugly-as-swat-guns-down-marine-vet/ | first=David | last=Axe | date=30 May 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601230745/https://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/05/drug-raid-turns-ugly-as-swat-guns-down-marine-vet/ | archive-date=2011-06-01 | dead-url=no |quote=<blockquote>One thing is clear. With military-grade vehicles, armor, assault weapons and robots, the raid on Guerena's home was all but indistinguishable from the kind of house-clearing operations U.S. forces perform every day in Iraq and Afghanistan. Guerena survived two tours in the desert only to perish in a military-style action in his own home.</blockquote> }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Balko | first=Radley | title=Family Of Jose Guerena, Former Marine Killed By SWAT Team, To Receive $3.4 Million | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/26/jose-guerena_n_3988658.html | publisher=Huffington Post | accessdate=11 May 2017 | date=26 September 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930174402/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/26/jose-guerena_n_3988658.html | archive-date=2013-09-30 | dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{ cite news | url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-27/justice/arizona.marine.death_1_swat-team-internal-investigation-pima-county-sheriff-s-department?_s=PM:CRIME | title=Marine Never Fired On SWAT Officers Who Fatally Shot Him | date=27 May 2011 | author=Chuck Conder | work=CNN | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110917154556/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-27/justice/arizona.marine.death_1_swat-team-internal-investigation-pima-county-sheriff-s-department?_s=PM:CRIME | archive-date=2011-09-17 | dead-url=yes }}</ref><ref>{{ cite news | url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/swat-team-gunned-marine-find-drugs/story?id=13702756 | title=Drug SWAT Team That Gunned Down Ex-Marine Found No Drugs | date=27 May 2011 | author=Ellen Tumposky | work=ABC News | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528213726/http://abcnews.go.com/US/swat-team-gunned-marine-find-drugs/story?id=13702756 | archive-date=2011-05-28 | dead-url=no | quote=<blockquote>But protests in the community continue. Guerena's widow will join members of the Oathkeepers, a group of veterans and law-enforcement officials, for a Memorial Day rally Monday at the Guerena home . The Oathkeepers say on their website that they are determined "to take a stand against the egregious policy of using SWAT teams to serve search warrants on veterans and gun owners with no violent criminal history.</blockquote> }}</ref>
Referring to the 2011 [[Occupy Wall Street]] protests in [[New York City]], Glen Greenwald wrote, "The police response was so excessive, and so clearly modeled after battlefield tactics, that there was no doubt that deterring domestic [[dissent]] is one of the primary aims of police militarization."<ref>{{cite web| url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2014/08/14/militarization-u-s-police-dragged-light-horrors-ferguson/| author=Glenn Greenwald| title=The Militarization of U.S. Police: Finally Dragged Into the Light by the Horrors of Ferguson| publisher=The Intercept| date=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
The [[Oakland Police Department]] (OPD) used excessive force while breaking up [[Occupy Oakland]] demonstrations in 2011. Several protesters successfully sued the city of [[Oakland, California]] for their injuries; Scott Olsen was severely injured after being hit in the head with a police projectile and was awarded $4.5 million. The city paid $1.17 million to a group of protesters, and $645,000 to Kayvan Sabeghi, who was clubbed by police.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.thenation.com/article/179351/did-occupy-actually-make-police-departments-more-accountable| author=Amity Paye |title=Did Occupy Actually Make Police Departments More Accountable?| work=The Nation| date=April 15, 2014}}</ref> [[File:Police sharpshooter at Ferguson protests.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A police [[sniper]] with a [[sniper rifle|sniper system]] provides [[overwatch (military tactic)|overwatch]] at the Ferguson protest regarding the [[shooting of Michael Brown]].]]
On May 28, 2014, a SWAT team looking for drugs in a [[Cornelia, Georgia]] home threw a [[flashbang grenade]] into the house. The grenade landed in the playpen of a 19-month-old baby boy, and the detonation severely burned and mutilated the baby's face.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.ajc.com/news/news/breaking-news/toddler-critically-injured-by-flash-bang-during-po/nf9XM/ | title=Toddler critically injured by 'flash bang' during police search | date=May 29, 2014 | accessdate=May 30, 2014}}</ref>
In late 2014, concerns about the militarization of police arose after the [[shooting of Michael Brown]] occurred on {{nowrap|August 9}}, 2014, in [[Ferguson, Missouri]], a [[suburb]] of {{nowrap|[[St. Louis]]}}.
